title: Managing Healthcare Appointments
description: Learn how to prepare for appointments, communicate effectively with healthcare providers, and ensure proper follow-up care.

content.overview: Good preparation helps you make the most of your time with your doctor and ensures you get the care you need.

gather_information: List of current medications (including vitamins and supplements)
Previous medical records if seeing a new doctor
Completed paperwork if it was sent to you
prepare_your_concerns: Write down your symptoms - when they started, how often, how severe
List your questions in order of importance
Note what makes symptoms better or worse
Think about what you want from this visit
practical_preparation: Confirm the appointment date, time, and location
Know where to park or how to get there
Bring something to do in case you wait

what_to_wear: Comfortable, easy-to-remove clothing if physical exam expected
Wear glasses or hearing aids if you use them

content.overview: Asking the right questions helps you understand your health and make informed decisions about your care.
about_your_diagnosis: What is my diagnosis? Can you explain it in simple terms?
Is this condition serious? Will it get worse?
Are there any tests I need? What are they looking for?
When and how will I get test results?
about_treatment: What are the benefits and risks of each option?
What happens if I do nothing?
How soon will the treatment start working?
What side effects should I watch for?
Are there lifestyle changes that could help?
Will I need to see a specialist?
about_medications: How and when do I take it?
What should I do if I miss a dose?
Are there foods, drinks, or activities I should avoid?
Will this interact with my other medications?
Is there a generic version available?
How long will I need to take this?
about_procedures_or_surgery: Why do I need this procedure?
What are the risks and benefits?
How long until I can return to normal activities?
Who will perform the procedure and what is their experience?
about_follow_up: Do I need a follow-up appointment?
What symptoms should I watch for?
When should I call if something is wrong?
Who do I contact if I have questions after I leave?
What should I do if symptoms get worse?

ask_me_3.description: A simple approach recommended by health literacy experts
questions: What do I need to do?
Why is it important for me to do this?

teach_back.description: Repeat back what you understood to make sure you got it right
teach_back.example: So just to make sure I understand, I should take this pill once a day in the morning with food, right?

content.overview: How you communicate during your appointment affects the quality of care you receive.

be_honest: Tell the truth about symptoms, even if embarrassing
Be accurate about your lifestyle (smoking, alcohol, diet)
Share all medications including over-the-counter and supplements
Mention if you have not been taking medications as prescribed
be_specific: Give timeframes (started 3 days ago, happens twice a week)
Explain what makes it better or worse
Describe exactly where symptoms are located
stay_focused: Start with your most important concern
Ask for clarification if you do not understand

take_notes: Write down key points during the visit
Ask if you can record the conversation (with permission)
if_you_do_not_understand: Ask the doctor to explain again
Ask for written information to take home
Ask if there are pictures or diagrams that might help
Use teach-back: repeat what you understood
if_you_disagree: Request a second opinion if needed
your_rights: Ask about any procedure before it happens
Have a chaperone during physical exams
Ask for a different provider if uncomfortable

content.overview: Understanding and acting on your after visit summary is essential for continuing your care properly.

after_visit_summary.what_it_is: A document summarizing your visit that you should receive before leaving
should_include: Tests ordered and how to get results
what_to_do: Ask questions if anything is unclear
Keep it with your medical records
Share with family members helping with your care

diet_changes: What foods should I eat or avoid?

following_up_on_tests.follow_up_if_no_news: Call if you do not hear back in the expected timeframe
following_up_on_tests.do_not_assume: No news does not always mean good news - always confirm results
following_up_on_tests.accessing_results: Many results available through patient portals

scheduling_follow_up.before_leaving: Schedule follow-up appointments before you leave if possible
scheduling_follow_up.set_reminders: Add appointments to your calendar with reminders
scheduling_follow_up.keep_track: Maintain a list of all upcoming appointments

call_immediately: Fever or signs of infection after procedures
who_to_call: Your doctor's office during business hours

content.overview: When you see multiple healthcare providers, coordination becomes essential to ensure safe and effective care.

create_a_system: Use a calendar (paper or electronic) for all appointments
Keep a folder for medical paperwork
Maintain updated lists of providers, medications, and conditions
Use a notebook to track questions and information

information_to_track.includes: Name, specialty, phone, address, patient portal info
Name, dose, frequency, prescribing doctor, reason
Date, test type, results, next steps

designate_quarterback.description: Usually your primary care provider coordinates all your care
their_role: Helps you understand the big picture

share_information: Bring medication list to every appointment
Tell each doctor about other doctors you see
Report changes in treatment to all providers
prevent_problems: Ask each doctor if new medication interacts with existing ones
Confirm which doctor is responsible for which aspects of care
Do not assume doctors communicate with each other automatically

prepare_differently_for_different_visits.preparation: Complete health history update, questions about preventive care
Focused questions about your specific condition, records from other providers
Update on how treatment is working, questions about next steps
Detailed symptom description, timeline, what you have tried

make_appointments_count: Cluster appointments when possible to reduce trips
Schedule important appointments when you are at your best
Allow time between appointments if you have multiple on one day
Book follow-ups before leaving current appointments

care_conferences.what_they_are: Meetings with multiple providers to discuss your care
care_conferences.when_helpful: Complex conditions, conflicting recommendations, major treatment decisions
care_conferences.how_to_request: Ask your primary care doctor or case manager to arrange

care_managers.who_they_are: Nurses or social workers who help coordinate complex care
care_managers.how_to_access: Ask your insurance company, hospital, or doctor's office

content.overview: Virtual appointments allow you to see healthcare providers from home using video or phone. Proper preparation ensures effective care.

types_of_telehealth.description: Face-to-face appointment through video on computer, tablet, or phone
types_of_telehealth.best_for: Most conditions that do not require physical exam

types_of_telehealth.description: Secure messaging back and forth with provider

appropriate_uses: Skin rashes (if can show on camera)
Minor injuries (if can show on camera)
not_appropriate_for: Conditions requiring physical exam or tests

technical_preparation: Find the link or instructions for joining
Know who to call if technical problems occur
environment_preparation: Ensure good lighting (light facing you, not behind)
Have a stable surface for your device
medical_preparation: If relevant, have blood pressure or other home readings
Wear loose clothing if you need to show a body part
Have thermometer available if discussing fever

during_the_visit: Look at the camera to simulate eye contact
Speak clearly and at a normal pace
Ask the provider to repeat if audio is unclear
Show any visible symptoms on camera
Take notes or ask for a written summary
privacy_and_security: Use secure platforms provided by your healthcare provider
Ensure you are in a private space
Avoid public WiFi for sensitive health discussions
Know that telehealth visits are part of your medical record

content.overview: Everyone deserves healthcare they can understand. If English is not your primary language or cultural factors affect your care, there are resources and rights to help.

your_rights: Free interpreter services at healthcare facilities receiving federal funding
Translated vital documents in common languages
No reliance on family members (including children) as interpreters for medical discussions
how_to_access: Request telephone interpretation if in-person not available

tips_for_interpreted_appointments: Speak directly to your doctor, not the interpreter
Use short sentences and pause for interpretation
Ask for clarification if the interpretation seems unclear
Request the interpreter repeat anything you did not understand
avoid_using: Family members for complex medical discussions
Bilingual staff not trained as medical interpreters

communicate_your_needs: Alternative medicine or traditional remedies you use
finding_culturally_competent_care: Ask if providers have experience with your community
Look for health centers serving your cultural group
Ask about availability of providers who speak your language
Inquire about cultural liaisons or patient navigators

you_have_the_right_to: Written materials at appropriate reading level
strategies: Ask for explanations in plain language
Request written materials in your language
Bring someone to help with communication

key_vocabulary.definition: A document summarizing your appointment including diagnoses, treatments, and next steps
Repeating information back to confirm you understood correctly
Healthcare delivered through video, phone, or messaging technology
Organizing care activities between multiple providers to ensure safe and effective treatment
A person who translates spoken language to help communication between people who speak different languages

action_items.why: Having information organized helps you get better care
Ensures you address your most important concerns

action_items.action: Always get an after visit summary
action_items.why: Provides written record of your care plan

action_items.action: Keep all providers informed about each other
action_items.why: Prevents medication interactions and gaps in care
